articles.title: Before we become fossils
articles.author: Aslan Shand
articles.summary: Colombia and Vanuatu announced the First International Conference for the Phase-Out of Fossil Fuels in 2026. IEA announced in 2021 that to limit global warming to 1.5°C, no new oil and gas fields or coal mines should be approved for development. The 2025 Production Gap Report by the Stockholm Environment Institute, Climate Analytics, and the International Institute for Sustainable Development was released on 22 September. It is based on plans from 20 major producing countries, including the US, Saudi Arabia, Brazil, the UAE, Australia, the UK, Norway, Russia and India. Australia's government's 2035 net zero climate modelling response was a large range target to cut

articles.title: Alberta seeing more avian flu cases in wild birds heading into migratory season
articles.author: Angela Amato
articles.summary: Alberta's environment ministry reports 41 confirmed cases of avian flu in wild birds in September. Waterfowl and shorebirds pass through Alberta and share the viruses with local wild birds which may not have the same level of immunity. Avian flu is a pathogenic virus, transmitting primarily through fluids and feces.

articles.title: Daylight saving time begins this Sunday
articles.author: Staff writers
articles.summary: Australians will lose an hour of sleep this weekend as daylight saving time officially begins on Sunday, 5 October. The time difference with Greece will be 8 hours for three weeks, until Sunday, 26 October, when winter time will be applied there, making it 9 hours.

articles.title: Vancouver, you just saw a record-breaking September
articles.author: Forecast Centre
articles.summary: September is the warmest on record in Vancouver thanks to unseasonably warm daytime highs and elevated nighttime lows. The average daily mean temperature for the month came in at almost 17°C. September's average minimum temperature was 13.4°C, which is more than two degrees warmer than normal.

articles.title: Coastal warnings for rough seas in KwaZulu-Natal
articles.author: Nozibusiso Mazibuko
articles.summary: KwaZulu-Natal residents are urged to prepare for hazardous conditions. The forecaster Mpho Rasimphi warned of some damaging winds. Inland parts of the province face extreme heat with temperatures climbing into the mid-30s. The Eastern Cape and Northwest are forecast to receive above-normal rainfall.

articles.title: Are fuel reduction burns making bushfires worse? Research from ANU says this might be the case
articles.author: Leon Compton
articles.summary: David Lindenmayer believes that more fuel reduction makes it harder to manage landscapes. He thinks that we need to rethink where we do prescribed burning and focus on protecting people and property. He also thinks that more people die from smoke related respiratory issues than they do from wildfires.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers shrank 3pc this year, fourth-biggest retreat on record
articles.summary: Glacier volume in Switzerland has dropped by 3% this year due to global warming. Switzerland is home to nearly 1,400 glaciers, the most of any country in Europe. More than 1,000 small glaciers in Switzerland have already disappeared due to climate change.

articles.title: Two New Blobs In the Atlantic, Any US Threat?
articles.author: The Weather Channel
articles.summary: There are two new areas being watched by the National Hurricane Center. One is just off the coast of Florida, expected to soak the East Coast. The other hasn't moved off the west coast of Africa, but will be monitored as well. Here's the latest information.

articles.title: World is more ablaze now with fires than in the 80s
articles.summary: The number of catastrophic wildfires has increased 4.4 times from 1980 to 2023. Europe and North America lead in the number of these economically damaging fires, especially in the Mediterranean, Italy, Spain and Portugal. People are moving closer to fire-prone areas called the wildland-urban interface.

articles.title: Calls for major daylight savings change impacting millions of Aussies: 'It's time'
articles.author: Joe Attanasio
articles.summary: Clocks will change at 2am on Sunday, October 5, jumping to 3am in NSW, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania, and the ACT. It will end on March 2, 2026, when clocks are turned back one hour. The Country Women's Association of New South Wales supports a reduction of daylight saving to four months, running from October to February.

articles.title: Calls for major daylight savings change impacting millions of Aussies: 'It's time'
articles.author: Joe Attanasio
articles.summary: Clocks will change at 2am on Sunday, October 5, jumping to 3am in NSW, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania, and the ACT. It will end on March 2, 2026, when clocks are turned back one hour. The Country Women's Association of New South Wales supports a reduction of daylight saving to four months, running from October to February.

articles.title: Record-breaking October heat expected for Australian capital
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: It's going to be the warmest October day for Brisbane since 2021. It will be 39 degrees in Rockhampton, while Ipswich, Gympie and Logan will reach the mid-30s. Sydney had its second-hottest September ever. It was the wettest September in 146 years early in September.

articles.title: All you need to know about daylight saving and why one state brought it back after drought
articles.author: Carla Mascarenhas
articles.summary: Clocks will move forward by one hour on Sunday, October 5, at 2am in NSW, Victoria, ACT, Tasmania and South Australia, marking the return of Daylight Saving Time (DST). Clocks move forward during the warmer months so that evenings have more daylight and mornings have less, allowing for better use of natural daylight. Tasmania was the first state to bring DST back in 1967 after its temporary use during World War I in 1916. Queensland, Western Australia and Northern Territory do not have DST.

articles.title: All you need to know about daylight saving and why one state brought it back after drought
articles.author: Carla Mascarenhas
articles.summary: Clocks will move forward by one hour on Sunday, October 5 at 2 am in NSW, Victoria, ACT, Tasmania and South Australia. It's the return of Daylight Saving Time (DST) for the first time since 2003.   Â

articles.title: All you need to know about daylight saving and why one state brought it back after drought
articles.author: Carla Mascarenhas
articles.summary: Clocks will move forward by one hour on Sunday, October 5, at 2am in NSW, Victoria, ACT, Tasmania and South Australia. DST was introduced by Tasmania in 1967 after a drought decimated the state's hydroelectric power supply. In 1971, NSW, Queensland, South Australia, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory adopted DST, while Western Australia and the Northern Territory did not.

articles.title: Morning Mail: Nauru asylum seekers ‘going hungry', ATO hunt for old debts, UK synagogue attack
articles.author: Martin Farrer
articles.summary: Two people were killed in a terror attack on a synagogue in Manchester. Refugees and asylum seekers held on Nauru claim they can't afford to eat and are forced to skip meals. Hamas is expected to demand key revisions to Donald Trump's peace plan. China's apparent ban on BHP iron ore shipments has sparked alarm about the potential impact on the Australian economy.

articles.title: World Experts to Rally at the 5th Annual Florida Climate Conference: Climate & Biodiversity
articles.summary: On November 13, 2025, the Climate Adaptation Center (CAC) hosts its 5th Annual Florida Climate Conference, "Climate and Biodiversity" at the University of South Florida Sarasota-Manatee campus. Global temperatures have already surged past the critical 1.5°C threshold above pre-industrial levels for the first time in human history. Today's warming is 20 times faster than the recovery from the last Ice Age.

articles.title: Multnomah County's Climate Justice Plan Progresses Amid Public Input and Calls for Actionable Measures
articles.author: Amina Rashid
articles.summary: Multnomah County's Climate Justice Plan was developed with the collaboration of a steering committee, comprising 13 community-based organizations. The plan aims to prioritize those hit hardest by climate change, emphasizing heat waves, wildfires, smoke, and other extreme weather conditions exacerbated by fossil fuels. The Board of County Commissioners is set for a final work session and a vote on the plan.

articles.title: Dual hurricanes send beach homes crashing into the ocean
articles.author: Dennis Mersereau
articles.summary: Hurricanes Humberto and Imelda caused waves to batter North Carolina's Outer Banks this week. Seven beachfront homes collapsed into the ocean in Buxton on Hatteras Island on Tuesday and Wednesday. Most of the homes that collapsed were built in the 1970s and 1980s.

articles.title: Costly and deadly wildfires really are on the rise, new research finds
articles.author: Rebecca Dzombak
articles.summary: The number of disastrous wildfires has increased more than fourfold from 1980 to 2023. Nearly half of the fires, 43%, were in the last 10 years of the record. Climate change can make fire seasons longer, hotter and drier, which sets the stage for damaging fires in urban settings.

articles.title: B.C. ostrich owner condemns violence near embattled farm
articles.author: Glen Hallick
articles.summary: The owner of Universal Ostrich near Edgewood, B.C. condemned the alleged assault and arson against one of the farm's neighbours. The incident occurred on Sept. 22 and the alleged perpetrator was arrested without incident. He was later released with the promise not to return to the area. Some of the ostriches on the farm contracted avian influenza and the remaining ones were ordered to be culled. The matter has gone to the Supreme Court of Canada. The court has already granted a stay of the cull.

articles.title: Heat-related deaths in Spain up 88 per cent from last year
articles.summary: There were 3,832 heat-related deaths in Spain between May 16 and September 30. This is an 87.6-per cent increase from the same period in 2024. Almost two-thirds of the deaths involved people over the age of 85, and almost 96 per cent were over 65. Spain this year sweltered through its hottest summer since records began in 1961.

articles.title: Costly and Deadly Wildfires Really Are on the Rise, New Research Finds
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: The past decade has seen an uptick in devastating blazes linked to climate change, according to a new study. The study was based on data from the Global Change Project.       iReport.com: What do you think? Share your thoughts.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers shrunk three per cent this year
articles.author: The Pioneer
articles.summary: Glacier volume in Switzerland has dropped by 3% this year due to global warming. Switzerland is home to nearly 1,400 glaciers, the most of any country in Europe. The ice mass has declined by one-quarter over the last decade, according to the scientists.

articles.title: Do you know who is visiting your place when you're out? It's time to check in
articles.author: Megan Backhouse
articles.summary: BirdLife Australia has organised its 12th annual Aussie Bird Count. People are asked to record what they see in a specific area over a period of 20 minutes. Last year's count attracted more than 57,000 participants. The data collected adds to the scientific knowledge about the health of bird populations and habitat around Australia.

articles.title: Daylight saving is almost here. This is what you need to know
articles.author: Daniel Lo Surdo
articles.summary: Clocks will be set forward on Sunday as daylight saving time begins in Australia. Digital clocks will move forward to 3am. Analog clocks will need to be manually adjusted. Daylight saving time applies in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory.

articles.title: Daylight saving is almost here. This is what you need to know
articles.author: Daniel Lo Surdo
articles.summary: Clocks will be set forward on Sunday as daylight saving time begins in Australia. Digital clocks will move forward to 3am. Analog clocks will need to be manually adjusted. Daylight saving time applies in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory.

articles.title: Do you know who is visiting your place when you're out? It's time to check in
articles.summary: The same three large birds keep turning up at the annual bird count. More than 57,000 Australians participated in this annual count last year, and the same three birds kept turning up. The bird count is organised by the Australian National Bird Census Board.

articles.title: Daylight saving is almost here. This is what you need to know
articles.summary: Daylight saving time is approaching. Clocks will move forward one hour in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory at 2 am on Sunday, October 5th.       .   in the rest of Australia.

articles.title: The surging price tag of wildfires, in one chart
articles.summary: The number of wildfires has risen dramatically in the last few years, driven by some of the hottest, driest conditions ever recorded. Of the 200 most costly fires on record, 43% were in the past decade. The frequency of fires that killed 10 or more people increased by a factor of 3.1 between 1980 and 2023, while the global population increased by 1.8%. The effects of more expensive wildfires are already rippling through businesses and banks around the world.

articles.title: Another round of heat records broken across Manitoba
articles.summary: The first day of October brought another bout of record-breaking heat across Manitoba. 10 communities set new heat records on Wednesday, including Churchill, Flin Flon, Gillam, Lynn Lake, Norway House, Thompson, Grand Rapids and The Pas. The only southern Manitoba community to set a new heat record was Gimli with a high of 25.7 C.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers melted at an ‘enormous' rate in 2025 — thanks in part to Europe's scorching summer
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers have suffered a 3% drop in total volume this year. The shrinkage is the fourth-largest annual drop on record. More than 1,000 small glaciers in Switzerland have already disappeared. Glaciers are retreating due to climate change caused by human activity.

articles.title: Heat-related deaths in Spain up 88% from last year- health ministry
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: There were 3,832 heat-related deaths in Spain between May 16 and September 30. This is an 87.6-percent increase from the same period in 2024. Almost two-thirds of the deaths involved people over the age of 85, and almost 96 percent were over 65. Spain this year sweltered through its hottest summer since records began in 1961.

articles.title: Study shows the world is far more ablaze now with damaging fires than in the 1980s
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: Europe and North America lead in the number of catastrophic fires. The frequency of these events has increased about 4.4 times from 1980 to 2023. 43% of the 200 most damaging fires occurred in the last 10 years. The Mediterranean around Greece, Italy, Spain and Portugal and the Western U.S. around California are worst affected.

articles.title: Study shows the world is far more ablaze now with damaging fires than in the 1980s
articles.author: Seth Borenstein
articles.summary: Earth's nastiest and costliest wildfires are burning four times more often now than in the 1980s because of human-caused climate change and people moving closer to wildlands, a new study finds. The study concludes there has been a 'climate-linked escalation of societally disastrous wildfires'

articles.title: Study shows the world is far more ablaze now with damaging fires than in the 1980s
articles.author: Seth Borenstein
articles.summary: Earth's nastiest and costliest wildfires are blazing four times more often now than in the 1980s because of human-caused climate change and people moving closer to wildlands. Europe and North America lead in the number of these economically damaging fires, especially in Mediterranean around Greece, Italy, Spain and Portugal and in the Western United States around California.

articles.title: Costly and Deadly Wildfires Really Are on the Rise, New Research Finds
articles.summary: The past decade has seen a significant uptick in costly, deadly fires. The number of disastrous wildfires has increased more than fourfold from 1980 to 2023. Nearly half of the fires, 43 percent, were in the last 10 years of the record. There were 43 wildfire disasters that cost more than $1 billion in that period. The disastrous fires were largely clustered in the western part of North America, southern Europe and southern Australia.

articles.title: Wildfires are getting deadlier and costing more. Experts warn they're becoming unstoppable
articles.author: Graham Readfearn
articles.summary: For the first time scientists have shown unambiguously that the numbers of 'societally disastrous' wildfires have increased around the world as a result of climate change. Of the 200 most damaging fires since 1980, 43% happened in the last 10 years, and half of the fires that cost US$1bn or more were also in that period. The frequency of fires causing 10 or more deaths tripled, while the population only went up by 1.8 times.

articles.title: Costly and Deadly Wildfires Really Are on the Rise, New Research Finds
articles.author: Rebecca Dzombak
articles.summary: The past decade has seen a significant uptick in costly, deadly fires, according to a new study published in the journal in Science. Climate change can make fire seasons longer, hotter and drier, and humans have been artificially suppressing wildfire for decades, which creates more fuel for fires.

articles.title: The surging price tag of wildfires, in one chart
articles.author: Umair Irfan
articles.summary: This year's wildfires in Los Angeles were likely the costliest on record. The European Union this year suffered its worst wildfire season since tracking began in 2006. The number of devastating wildfires has risen dramatically in the past few years, driven by some of the hottest, driest conditions ever recorded. Such fires will put a greater strain on governments and financial systems.

articles.title: Quebec's fall colours delayed this year, but interactive map tracks peak spots
articles.author: Marisela Amador
articles.summary: A new interactive map gives a real-time look at where to find Quebec's brightest colours. This year, the autumn foliage has had to wait longer than usual due to drought and cooler temperatures. However, since the beginning of September, the temperatures have been stable and warm.

articles.title: Heat-related deaths in Spain up 88% from last year
articles.summary: There were 3,832 heat-related deaths in Spain between May 16 and September 30. This is an 87.6-percent increase from the same period in 2024. Most of the deaths involved people over the age of 85, and almost 96 percent were over 65. Spain this year sweltered through its hottest summer since records began in 1961.

articles.title: Haya Farmers' Views on Climate Change Risks in Agriculture
articles.author: Bioengineer
articles.summary: T.F. Theodory's research focuses on the perceptions of climate change risks among Haya smallholder farmers in Missenyi and Muleba districts in Tanzania. The alteration of weather patterns, including erratic rainfall and shifting temperatures, has immediate and long-term consequences for crop yields. Many farmers have noticed changes in their local climate over the past few years, but their capacity to respond effectively is limited by socio-economic barriers.

articles.title: Baltimore deserves chance to hold fossil fuel companies accountable
articles.author: Andre M. Davis
articles.summary: The effects of climate change are here and now for Baltimore City. With over 60 miles of waterfront, the city is at high risk from floods and inundation caused by sea level rise. In 2018, Baltimore City filed a lawsuit against fossil fuel companies. The lower court dismissed the city's claims before a trial could take place. Now, the Supreme Court of Maryland will hear arguments from Baltimore in its appeal.

articles.title: Lawsuits won't deliver real climate solutions
articles.author: Mary D. Kane
articles.summary: Maryland's highest court is set to hear appeals in climate lawsuits filed by Baltimore, Annapolis and Anne Arundel County on Oct. 6. At issue is whether these local governments can use Maryland civil law to regulate global emissions related to climate change. Two Maryland judges have already answered no. The business community in Maryland powers the state's economy.

articles.title: Greencastle Harbour €16 million breakwater investment ‘in vain' without dredging
articles.author: Damian Dowds
articles.summary: Donegal County Council has invested €16 million in constructing a new breakwater at Greencastle Harbour. The silt build-up in the harbour has made berths unusable outside of high water. Fishermen have reported extra costs, including overtime for co-op workers when high tides occur overnight and vessels have no time to safely land their catch.

articles.title: No, Reuters, Climate Change is Not Threatening Europe's Resources
articles.author: Anthony Watts
articles.summary: Reuters claims that climate change is a threat to Europe's natural resources. History shows far worse droughts in the past with no trend of other types of extreme weather events becoming more common or severe. Europe's resource problems are caused by humans, stemming from overuse and poor management, just not from climate change.

articles.title: BMS issues advisory on potential rough seas this weekend
articles.author: Nationnews Desk
articles.summary: Barbados Meteorological Services (BMS) is advising the public of possible deterioration in marine conditions around the island this weekend, linked to an area of low pressure in the northern Atlantic. Choppy sea conditions are expected, particularly along the western and northern coastlines and in open waters. Northerly swells of 1.5 to 2.5 metres are likely from Saturday and could persist into early next week.

articles.title: Video: Big changes in temperature on the way
articles.author: Cindy Fitzgibbon
articles.summary: Temperatures are going to get cooler this week. It's going to be in the 50s in most places and 60s at the coast. There's a big high pressure system coming out of Canada and it's moving away from Boston and into the Atlantic Ocean.

articles.title: Ghana at a crossroads: How climate change and environmental mismanagement threaten our economic future
articles.author: Peter Justice
articles.summary: Ghana is on the frontline of the global climate crisis. It is a vulnerable nation bearing the brunt of rising temperatures, erratic rainfall, deforestation, and environmental degradation. Peter Justice Gariba is a lawyer and environmentalist. He is based in Ghana.

articles.title: 50°C Paris is no longer sci-fi
articles.author: Catherine Porter
articles.summary: Eight of the 10 hottest summers recorded in Paris since 1900 occurred since 2015. Climate change is warming Europe at more than twice the global average. Imagine Paris at 50°C. The asphalt streets would melt in spots. The lights and fans could cut out in neighbourhoods if underground cables burned or junction boxes shifted.

articles.title: How can hurricanes hundreds of miles away cause North Carolina coastal homes to collapse?
articles.author: Rachel Duensing
articles.summary: Huge waves from hurricanes Imelda and Humberto caused houses to fall into the ocean in Buxton, N.C. According to the Cape Hatteras National Seashore, 18 structures have collapsed into the sea since 2020. By 2050, a coastal flood of 3 feet is expected every year for Dare County in North Carolina.

articles.title: ‘Rogue planet' growing at fastest rate ever observed by scientists
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: A "rogue planet" is growing at a record-breaking rate of six billion tons per second, according to new research. It's a planet growing at the rate of 6 billion tons a second. It is the fastest growing planet in the history of the universe.

articles.title: September hotter than entire summer average across much of Alberta
articles.author: David Opinko
articles.summary: The Weather Network says September was hotter than the rest of the summer. Lethbridge, Calgary, Red Deer and Edmonton were among the cities that experienced higher temperatures in September than the average for June, July and August. The average temperature in September, including all times of the day, was higher than in the previous three months.

articles.title: 7 houses collapse in less than 2 days as hurricanes roar off East Coast
articles.author: Dinah Voyles Pulver
articles.summary: Humberto and Imelda made a mess of the Atlantic Ocean in the coastal waters off North Carolina's Outer Banks. Five unoccupied houses collapsed on Sept. 30, another one on Oct. 1, and the seventh one on October 1, around 8 p.m. The total number of houses that have been lost to the ocean since May 2020 is 19.

articles.title: West African insurers tap climate risks as farmers, household losses rises
articles.author: Modestus Anaesoronye
articles.summary: In 2022, weather, climate, and water-related hazards affected more than 110 million people in Africa, causing more than $ 8.5 billion in economic damages and leading to at least 5,000 fatalities. In response, the insurers under the umbrella body of West African Insurance Companies Association (WAICA) are considering climate-focused products and risk models aimed at protecting livelihoods and building resilience in some of the continent's most climate-exposed communities. This will form the subject of discussion at the 2025 WAICA Educational. Conference in Lagos from the 12th to 15th October. Doris Uzoka-Anite, the minister of State, Ministry of Finance, has confirmed to

articles.title: WSJ Opinion: And End To Climate Alarmism
articles.author: Wsj Opinion
articles.summary: Donald Trump called the climate change movement a 'con job' at the UN last week. Ted Nordhaus, co-founder and director of the Breakthrough Institute, has changed his mind in recent years. He believes government incentives have created a 'climate industrial complex' that promotes an alarmist message.

articles.title: When does daylight saving start again in Australia – and how can you adjust your body clock?
articles.author: Ima Caldwell
articles.summary: Clocks will move forward one hour this Sunday in many parts of Australia as the weather warms up. New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory all observe daylight saving. Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory do not. Fair Work Ombudsman recommends employees and employers check their award or registered agreement for terms on daylight saving time.

articles.title: Isabela folk rush to brace homes against tropical storm Paolo
articles.author: Gma Integrated News
articles.summary: Isabela residents are stocking up on food and other essential supplies, and reinforcing their homes against the strong winds and rains expected to hit the province due to tropical storm Paolo. Residents in the towns of Dinapigue, Divilacan, Maconacon and Palanan have been warned against the threat of a storm surge.

articles.title: Gambia calls for transformational climate solutions at UNGA80
articles.author: The Point
articles.summary: Hon. Manjang highlights the climate change threat to agriculture in The Gambia. Rising seas are causing saline intrusion into rice fields. The Gambian economy is being devastated by climate change. There is a need for transformational solutions at scale to the climate crisis.

articles.title: Rising sea levels will flood over 2,650 Cork homes, report predicts
articles.author: Amy Campbell
articles.summary: One in every 100 homes in Cork could experience coastal flooding if sea levels continue to rise, which would result in more than €82m in insurance claims. The sea level has risen by 3.18mm per annum between 1993 and 2018. Extreme sea level events that are historically rare are projected to occur more frequently at least once per year by 2050 in Ireland.

articles.title: A bumper crop of bad science
articles.author: John Robson
articles.summary: CNN warned in June that climate change would cut world crop production dramatically, including by as much as 50% in the US, particularly in the United States, where production of kimberly is very low. The news has since been exaggerated and exaggerated to make a point.

articles.title: Climate change dialogue in Umgababa
articles.author: Vusi Mthalane
articles.summary: A FOCUS group was hosted by the South Durban Community Environmental Alliance (SDCEA) for a dialogue on climate change impacts in Umgababa on September 27. The engagement followed a similar one held a few days earlier in Durban and it centred around raising awareness of climate change and the steps to take to combat it.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers shrank 3% this year, the fourth-biggest retreat on record
articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.summary: Glaciers in Switzerland are retreating due to climate change caused by human activity. The shrinkage is the fourth-largest after those in 2022, 2023 and back in 2003. Glaciers are also having an impact on Switzerland's landscape, causing mountains to shift and ground to become unstable.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers shrank 3% this year, the fourth-biggest retreat on record
articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers have seen a 3% drop in total volume this year due to the effects of global warming. This is the fourth-largest annual drop on record. The shrinkage this year means that ice is melting faster than in the past.

articles.title: Cyclone in Arabian Sea: Rain expected in Karachi for two days
articles.author: Sana Fatima
articles.summary: Karachi is likely to receive rain for the next two days due to a developing cyclone in the Arabian Sea. Light to moderate rain is expected in Karachi, Tharparkar, Umerkot, Badin, Thatta, Sujawal, and Tando Muhammad Khan districts. Winds along the Sindh coast may reach 40 to 50 kilometers per hour, causing rough sea conditions. Fishermen are advised to avoid deep-sea ventures until October 3.

articles.title: The Great Fall Bird Migration Begins Across Kansas
articles.author: Kansas Public Radio
articles.summary: The fall migration of birds is underway and will continue into late October and early November in Kansas. Cheyenne Bottoms and Quivira National Wildlife Refuge are critical stopping points for the migration. Franklin's gulls roost at Clinton Lake, west of Lawrence from late September to October.

articles.title: 1,000 Swiss glaciers already gone, and the melting is speeding up
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Swiss glaciers lost nearly 3% of their volume in 2025, following a snow-poor winter and scorching summer heatwaves. The melt has been so because of the recent snow-free winter and hot summer heatwave.   Â

articles.title: Aussie capital city set to see scorching October
articles.summary: Two Aussie capital cities will feel the heat this month. One of them had its hottest October day in years, while the other one had its coldest October day ever.    - for details, go to: http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-news/2013/10/30/aussies-capital-cities-will-feel-the-heaviest-October-day-in-years-as-one-city-has-hottest-day in years-for-years.

articles.title: Aussie capital city set to see scorching October
articles.summary: Two Aussie capital cities will feel the heat this month. One of them had its hottest October day in years, while the other will have its hottest day in recent years.      Â   .   y   in

articles.title: Aussie capital city set to see scorching October
articles.summary: Aussie capital city is set to see scorching October. The feature is currently unavailable and we're working to restore it. Please try again later and don't be late for anything.    -   .  Â   y

articles.title: The exodus of oasis dwellers: In Mauritania, climate change is threatening date farmers
articles.author: Simon MARTIN
articles.summary: In the oasis of the Mauritanian Sahara, climate change is tightening its grip. Date palms are at risk because recent rainfall has not been enough to replenish them. This poses a major threat to farmers in a country where less than 0.5 percent of the land is arable.

articles.title: Deep Depression Nears Odisha Coast, IMD Hoists Cautionary Signals at Paradip, Gopalpur Ports
articles.author: Ananya Pattnaik
articles.summary: A deep depression over the Bay of Bengal is moving towards the Odisha coast. It is expected to make landfall between Gopalpur and Paradip by late Thursday night. Seven districts are on red alert, 16 districts on orange alert, and 7 districts on yellow alert. Local Cautionary Signal No. III has been hoisted at Paradip and other ports.

articles.title: Disease-carrying mosquito species are found in the UK as climate change fuels spread
articles.author: London Evening Standard
articles.summary: Experts believe climate change will make mosquito spread more common due to the increase in the number of mosquitoes and their spread due to climate change more common in the future due to increased temperatures and more people living in areas with more mosquitoes.   Â

articles.title: 2025 heatwaves shrink Swiss glaciers by 3%, fourth-biggest annual loss
articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers have seen a 3% decline in their volume this year. This is the fourth-largest annual decline on record. A winter with little snow and heatwaves in June and August contributed to the 3% loss of glacier volume. One-quarter of Switzerland's ice mass has decreased by a quarter over the last decade.

articles.title: Weather records fell across Saskatchewan
articles.author: Cody Glydon
articles.summary: This week, warm temperatures have made the first few days of autumn feel more like summer. September 30th saw a number of temperatures fall across the province. According to Precision Weather, temperatures will start to feel more 'October-like' starting this weekend. Saturday is predicted to be sunny and 18C, Sunday will be cloudy with a high of 10C and Monday is expected to be partly sunny with high of 12C.

articles.title: Gambia calls for transformational climate solutions at UNGA80
articles.author: Jankey Ceesay
articles.summary: Hon. Manjang highlights the deep vulnerabilities facing The Gambia due to climate change. The minister called for massive investment in agroecological climate-smart food systems, green industrialisation, nature-based restoration, and resilient infrastructure. She also urged the international community to strengthen partnerships and ensure scaled-up, direct, flexible, and rapid adaptation finance.

articles.title: Decline in porpoise sightings off Bardsey Island
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: The decline could be due to the impacts of climate change or because they are feeding elsewhere, as they are no longer in the area they used to be in.    .   i   in this case, it could be because of the decline due to climate change.

articles.title: Israel to deport Gaza flotilla activists
articles.summary: Israel will deport pro-Palestinian activists on an aid flotilla intercepted at sea as they headed towards Gaza. The Global Sumud Flotilla of around 45 vessels began its voyage last month with politicians and activists including Swedish climate campaigner Greta Thunberg heading to Gaza.

articles.title: Climate Change and Economy: Drivers of Inequitable Migration
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Study by Yang et al. seeks to unravel the complex web of influences that drive human movement, particularly in regions most vulnerable to the ramifications of a warming planet. They argue for comprehensive migration policies that take into account the nuances of climate impact and economic prospects for those displaced.

articles.title: Overwash and standing water reported along N.C. Highway 12 as storm event continues
articles.author: Joy Crist
articles.summary: N.C. Highway 12 on northern Ocracoke Island remains closed, with ferry service suspended, because of ocean overwash. Coastal Flood Warning remains in effect through Friday from Oregon Inlet to Cape Lookout. A seventh house collapsed in Buxton on Hatteras Island on Wednesday night, bringing the total number of collapsed homes on the island to 19.

articles.title: Recreational fires and general outdoor burning may resume in Kitsap on Oct. 3
articles.author: Peiyu Lin
articles.summary: Kitsap County will lift phase one and phase two burn bans on Friday, Oct. 3. The county received between 0.3 and 1.25 inches of rain in the past week. The weather is cooler and fuel moisture conditions have improved. Only natural vegetation grown on the property can be burned. Land clearing debris can't be used. Fires must be attended at all times until fully extinguished.

articles.title: New national park rules to hit campers in 2025
articles.author: Gavin C Robinson
articles.summary: Barbecues and campfires will be banned in Cairngorm National Park between 1 April and 30 September to protect the environment. The Herald's exclusive partnership with USA Today brought this article to you by its exclusive subscriber partnership with their sister title USA Today.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers shrank by three per cent this year, the fourth-biggest retreat on record
articles.author: Jamey Keaten
articles.summary: This year's shrinkage of Switzerland's glaciers is the fourth-largest annual drop on record due to the effects of global warming. A winter with low snow depth and heat waves in June and August led to a loss of 3% of the glacier volume. More than 1,000 small glaciers in Switzerland have already disappeared.

articles.title: Rethinking Development: A Call from the Himalayas
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat voiced concerns over India's development policies and their impact on the Himalayas during a speech in Nagpur on Thursday. He highlighted the recent natural calamities, inconsistent rainfall, increased landslides, and shrinking glaciers over the past few years.

articles.title: An Island Nation on the Front Lines of Climate Change
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: Hilda Heine, president of the Marshall Islands, discussed her nation's uncertain future as seas rise at a Climate Forward live event. She is concerned about the future of her nation.       .   in the context of climate change.

articles.title: Australia on the Front Lines of Climate Change
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: Anthony Albanese is the prime minister of Australia. He talked about his country's battles against the effects of climate change at a Climate Forward live event in Melbourne. He was speaking about Australia's fight against climate change.      Â

articles.title: Has the World Given Up on Fighting Climate Change?
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: At a Climate Forward event, David Wallace-Wells explores why global momentum on climate action is faltering, even though clean energy technology is rapidly advancing. He says it's due to the lack of political will to act on climate change, despite advances in clean energy.

articles.title: An Australian Magnate's Challenge to President Trump
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: Billionaire Andrew Forrest urged President Trump to visit Australia to see the effects of climate change at a Climate Forward live event in Sydney.       .   for support for climate change action. For more information, visit climateforward.org.

articles.title: 'Enormous' melting sees Swiss glaciers shrink by 3% this year, the fourth-biggest retreat on record
articles.author: euronews
articles.summary: Swiss glaciers shrink by 3% this year, the fourth-biggest retreat on record. Since 2015, glaciologists say Switzerland's glaciers have shrunk by a quarter. Euronews is available on Dailymotion in 12 languages and is available in English and German.

articles.title: Singapore GP declared F1's first 'heat hazard' race
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Singapore GP declared F1's first 'heat hazard' race. Temperatures are expected to reach 31C this weekend at the Singapore Grand Prix, which is the first in Formula 1 history to be declared a heat hazard race by the sport's governing body.

articles.title: Fall foliage on Mount Desert Island not yet in full swing
articles.author: Zach Lanning
articles.summary: The shutdown of the federal government might affect access to Acadia Nat'l Park, but it can't stop the seasonal symphony from occurring. The Earth's axial tilt of 23.5 degrees brings shorter days and colder temperatures to whichever hemisphere has moved farther away from the sun. Once trees begin to pick up on these changes, they start to prepare themselves for the winter months ahead.

articles.title: Historical Moment: Over 1.2 Million Years Of Earth's Climate History Captured From Antarctic Ice Core
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Beyond EPICA - Oldest Ice project has successfully analysed 190 metres of ice from the bottom of a 2800-metre ice core retrieved from Little Dome C in East Antarctica. Melting and analysis of the ice finishes this week. The data will undergo comprehensive analysis at laboratories across Europe to unlock secrets about the Earth's climate evolution and greenhouse gas concentrations.

articles.title: 5 most devastating climate disasters of 2025 so far
articles.author: Hania Jamil
articles.summary: This year has been one of the most destructive years on record for extreme weather. Several climate disasters have been caused by climate change. Southern California wildfires killed nearly 30 people and destroyed over 521,632 acres of land in California. Pakistan was hit by flooding and Super Typhoon Ragasa caused havoc in Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Southern China.

articles.title: Papua New Guinea Cabinet approves defense treaty with Australia
articles.author: Rod Mcguirk
articles.summary: Australia's and Papua New Guinea's prime ministers attended a flag lowering ceremony in Port Moresby on Sept. 16, 2025. They were joined by Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and PNG's PM James Marape. The ceremony took place in front of the Australian and PNG flags.

articles.title: Australia on the Front Lines of Climate Change
articles.author: Evan Roberts
articles.summary: The limited series from The New York Times features conversations about the growing threat of climate change with world leaders, business leaders and policymakers recorded live at the annual Climate Forward conference in New York City. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia spoke with Evan Roberts about the United States' withdrawal from global action on climate change and other issues Australia faces.

articles.title: An Australian Magnate's Challenge to President Trump
articles.author: Evan Roberts
articles.summary: Andrew Forrest, the C.E.O. of the global mining company Fortescue and the richest person in Australia, laid out his vision for a fossil-free future and the role heavy industry, green hydrogen and private capital must play in helping us arrive there. He also challenged President Trump to witness the ways climate change is transforming Australia.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers shrank 3 per cent this year, fourth-biggest retreat on record
articles.summary: This year's shrinkage of Switzerland's glaciers is the fourth-largest annual drop on record due to the effects of global warming. Switzerland is home to nearly 1,400 glaciers, the most of any country in Europe. The retreat and loss of glaciers is also having an impact on Switzerland's landscape.

articles.title: Scientists warn of mercury threat in ocean due to human activity
articles.author: CGTN
articles.summary: Continental shelves store nearly 1,300 tonnes of mercury each year. Bottom trawling and dredging disturb over 5,000 tonnes of Mercury in sediments annually. Rising temperatures enhance the release of mercury from sediments. The natural release of Mercury from the sediments could increase by 6 to 21 percent by the end of the century.

articles.title: Map reveals government's dramatic failure as $87 million 'crisis' sweeps Aussie state
articles.author: Michael Dahlstrom
articles.summary: Tasmanian government's five-year plan to stop the spread of a feral animal species is failing. Fallow deer numbers have increased by 20,000 between 2019 and 2024 in Tasmania. They are threatening 'high-value conservation areas' including the World Heritage-listed Walls of Jerusalem National Park and the sub-alpine Central Plateau Conservation Area. The Invasive Species Council warned deer are costing farmers $87 million a year.

articles.title: More than 1,000 small glaciers in Switzerland have already disappeared
articles.summary: This year's shrinkage of Switzerland's glaciers is the fourth-largest annual drop on record due to the effects of global warming. A winter with low snow depth and heatwaves in June and August led to a loss of 3 per cent of the glacier volume. More than 1,000 small glaciers in Switzerland have already disappeared.

articles.title: 21st Century Flood Risk Is Affected More By Policy Than Climate Threats
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: How governments choose to develop coastal regions is affecting exposure to flooding more than climate change. More than 700 million people live in China's coastal zone, which includes megacities like Shanghai, Guangzhou and Tianjin. Four hotspots are identified as being most at risk for floods: the three deltas of the Pearl, Yangtze, and Liaohe Rivers, and the Bohai Bay.

articles.title: New Study Attributes Arctic Sea Ice Decline – And ‘Slowdown' Since 2012 -To Internal Variability
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: There is a flat or slight decline in Arctic sea ice since 2012. It is due to natural decadal-scale variations in the North Atlantic Oscillation, Atlantic Multidecadal Oscilliation and "enhanced summertime radiation balance associated with an anticyclonic atmospheric circulation pattern". Alarmist predictions of an ice-free Arctic will be put on hold until after the 2030s.

articles.title: Arabian Sea Depression, at 440KM in south of Karachi
articles.summary: The low-pressure over the Arabian Sea has intensified into Depression 440 km south from Karachi. Karachi and other districts of southeastern Sindh could receive light to moderate rainfall. The weather department has predicted high waves and rough weather in the sea along Sindh's coastal belt. Fishermen have been warned not to venture into the deep sea until October 3.

articles.title: Labor Senator Says Australia Has 3rd Highest Rate of ‘Climate Denialism' in the World
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: A Labor senator says Australians are 'drowning' in counter-narratives against climate change ideology. Michelle Ananda-Rajah has asked the media watchdog to track the root cause. Australia has the third highest rate in the world of climate denialism.

articles.title: 'Anyone who's tried it wants more': Find out what sets this skincare apart
articles.author: Alise McIntosh
articles.summary: Ashlee Grives has worked in the great outdoors for 20 years. She has battled excruciating heat, piercing winds, and bitter cold. She's worked in extreme weather conditions. She works for a company that provides services in the outdoors. She is a professional outdoorswoman.

articles.title: Aussie capital set to see scorching October
articles.summary: Two Aussie capitals will feel the heat this month. One of them had its hottest October day in years, while the other one had its coldest October day ever.    - for confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local Samaritans branch or click here for details.

articles.title: Meet Kings' Barsha kid who went from Dubai karting tracks to Europe's podiums
articles.author: Gulf News
articles.summary: Lachlan Robinson, 22, is an Australian who grew up in Dubai. He calculated all the emissions of motorsport for this season, including the flights, the travel from the airports to the tracks, and the racing and testing as well as the emissions.

articles.title: Island Communities Press For all Hands On Deck Response To Climate Crisis
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Small island states and territories in the South Pacific, Indian Ocean and Caribbean are among the most climate-vulnerable regions in the world. They have a high level of belief in human-caused climate change and high levels of concern about climate-linked environmental threats. They support an "all hands on deck" approach to addressing the climate crisis.

articles.title: Extreme heat may speed up aging, just like smoking and heavy drinking
articles.summary: Long-term exposure to high temperatures can speed up biological aging. From heart strain to epigenetic changes, heat is wearing us down from the inside out. Click on to explore how heat may be silently aging you and what you can do to fight back.

articles.title: Kerry residents fear solar farm development in scenic area – ‘No one is going to want to live there'
articles.author: Jack Joy Kerryman
articles.summary: Lacka West, near Duagh, is one of the highest points in north Kerry, exceeding 200m above sea level in some parts. Locals fear that the development of a solar farm in their area could ruin its appearance and even pose a threat to life.

articles.title: Global protests after Gaza aid flotilla intercepted by Israeli forces
articles.author: Aria Chen
articles.summary: Protesters gathered in Turkey, Greece, Italy, Tunisia and Argentina after Israeli forces intercepted a fleet of vessels carrying aid to Gaza. Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg is among the passengers aboard the Global Sumud Flotilla and she is protesting against Israel's actions.

articles.title: Wild deer 'failure': unexpected jump in feral numbers
articles.author: Ethan James
articles.summary: Feral deer numbers are rising "markedly" and getting denser on the edge of high-conservation wilderness, according to a survey. Critics claim a management failure is to blame for the problem.       .   in the survey.

articles.title: 🌱 Patch AM: Asheville's communication systems still vulnerable a year later
articles.author: Patch AM Team
articles.summary: Asheville East KOA Holiday has reopened after extensive repairs from Hurricane Helene. Asheville City Council is considering changes to the noise ordinance to support local businesses affected by Helene and boost downtown activity. Silniva Online Auction and 9 more events are on the calendar today.

articles.title: Upcoming Adaptation Futures conference to showcase resilience
articles.summary: The 8th Adaptation Futures Conference is taking place in New Zealand from October 13-16. Vanuatu is one of the most at-risk countries in the world due to climate change. The island nation has 83 islands from across the South Pacific. It's exposure to rising sea levels, intensified tropical cyclones, and seismic activity in the Pacific 'Ring of Fire' places its communities on the frontlines of climate disruption.

articles.title: Switzerland's Glaciers: A Melting Crisis in 2025
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Switzerland's glaciers have experienced a 3% drop in total volume this year. This is the fourth largest annual decrease on record. The glacier monitoring group GLAMOS and the Swiss Academy of Sciences report that Switzerland has experienced a dramatic decline in ice mass by one-quarter over the last decade.

articles.title: Swift Glacier Retreat and Innovations in Human Reproductive Science
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Swiss glaciers have lost 3% of their ice mass due to minimal snowfall and a severe heatwave. This is the fourth-largest decrease in ice volume on record. In a separate scientific breakthrough, researchers are exploring the potential of developing human eggs from skin cells.

articles.title: Townsville braces for hottest October day in three years
articles.author: Daniel Shirkie
articles.summary: Townsville is set to have one of the hottest October days of the year on Friday, with a maximum temperature of 35 degrees. The current October record for North Queensland is 37.1 degrees, which was set back in 1958. The last time it was this hot in October was in 2022, on the 29th of October. The culprit for the heat is a trough sweeping in from the East. A local fire ban has been imposed for Charters Towers, Flinders and Richmond LGAs. It will be in place from the early hours of Friday.

articles.title: Alex Campbell
articles.author: Alex Campbell
articles.summary: It's been one year since Hurricane Helene hit western North Carolina. The storm caused $60 billion in damage in western NC, making it the costliest storm to hit the state. The combined funding for recovery from federal, state, and private sources is only $15 billion. Governor Josh Stein has asked for $13.5 billion in federal funding for Helene recovery, but there's still $45 billion in outstanding damages.

articles.title: Why climate models fail
articles.author: Douglas J. Cotton
articles.summary: Mainstream climatology models ignore the fact that gravity, not radiative forcing, governs the temperature gradient in the troposphere. In the absence of greenhouse gases, the equilibrium gradient can be derived from first principles. This has led to the discovery of the 'heat creep' process, which transfers solar energy from the upper atmosphere to the surface.

articles.title: Global financial stability risks have not receded, RBA warns
articles.author: system
articles.summary: The Reserve Bank warns risks to the global financial system are "rising", not receding. Australia is not immune from any fallout from the global economic crisis.       .   "RISK IS RISING, NOT receding".

articles.title: Growing migration trend prompts urgent backyard warning to Aussies: 'Not the same'
articles.author: Tom Flanagan
articles.summary: Firies are warning Aussies who've sold up in the city and moved to the country to prepare their properties for bushfires. Greater Geelong in Victoria overtook Queensland's Sunshine Coast to become the most popular destination for internal movers, according to the latest Regional Movers Index.

articles.title: Grave warning to Aussies who've fled capital cities for the country: 'Be aware'
articles.author: Tom Flanagan
articles.summary: Firies are warning Aussies who've sold up in the city and moved to the country to prepare their properties for bushfires. Greater Geelong in Victoria overtook Queensland's Sunshine Coast to become the most popular destination for internal movers, according to the latest Regional Movers Index.

articles.title: As the US retreats, is China the adult in the room in global efforts to mitigate climate change?
articles.author: Gideon H Chitanga
articles.summary: China set emissions targets at the UN Climate Summit attended by more than 100 world leaders. The announcement comes at a time when the United States is rolling back on its commitments towards climate change. The UN has previously said climate change might pose the biggest threat to humanity, something akin to an existential challenge. Developed and developing countries suffer the most from climate change impacts.

articles.title: Alleged arsonists arrested amid total fire ban as heatwave hits Queensland
articles.author: Sarah Keszler
articles.summary: A total fire ban has been declared for much of Queensland's north and southeast. Six grass fires were deliberately lit in Blackswamp, near Chinchilla on Wednesday night. A 27-year-old man from Wandoan was arrested and charged with setting fire to vegetation and possessing dangerous drugs. Another man, 34, from Monkland was charged with allegedly setting a fire to a cane field in Mackay and remanded in custody to face court on November 10.

articles.title: Rising Carbon Dioxide Crisis
articles.summary: The level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has reached an alarming stage. It is the highest in millions of years. It traps heat and traps CO2, causing global warming, extreme heatwaves, irregular rainfall, floods, droughts, melting glaciers, and rising sea levels. Carbon dioxide dissolves in oceans, forming carbonic acid. This process destroys marine life and coastal cities.

articles.title: CNA938 Rewind - Quakes and typhoons: What's driving the recent spate of climate phenomena?
articles.author: CNA
articles.summary: Recent weeks have seen a rise in seismic activity and intense typhoons across the globe. Andrea Heng and Hairianto Diman find out the reasons behind the recent spate of climate phenomena with Aron Meltzner, Assistant Professor, Earth Observatory of Singapore and Asian School of the Environment, NTU.

articles.title: COP out? Prospect of climate summit spanning Australia and Turkey raises carbon emissions question
articles.author: Mike Foley
articles.summary: Australia and Turkey are considering splitting hosting duties for next year's global climate summit. The Albanese government pledged in the 2025 election to bring the COP to Australia in 2026. It is unclear how the potential dual hosting duties would play out in practice and officials stressed that details would be subject to negotiation.

articles.title: COP out? Prospect of climate summit spanning Australia and Turkey raises carbon emissions question
articles.author: Mike Foley
articles.summary: Australia and Turkey are considering splitting hosting duties for next year's global climate summit. The Albanese government pledged in the 2025 election to bring the COP to Australia in 2026. Air travel accounts for about 2.5 per cent of annual global emissions, according to the International Energy Agency.

articles.title: These places in Saskatchewan broke heat records on Sept. 30
articles.author: Caitlin Brezinski
articles.summary: Some areas in Saskatchewan set new daily maximum temperature records for Sept. 30. Southerly winds brought unseasonably warm weather to much of the province on Tuesday. Elbow area set a new record of 31.9 C, beating the old record of 30 C set in 1992. Last Mountain Lake (Sanctuary) area, Lucky Lake area, Melfort area, Nipawin area, Wynyard area, Waskesiu Lake area and Watrous East area set new records.

articles.title: Japan's average temperature in Sept. marks 3rd highest
articles.author: Mainichi Japan
articles.summary: Japan's average temperature in September was 2.49 C higher than the mean temperature for 30 years from 1991 to 2020. The warmest September was in 2023, 2.66 C warmer than the baseline, and the warmest in 2024 2.52 C higher. The weather agency expects the higher-than-usual temperatures to continue.

articles.title: Pacific Ocean Portal relaunched: A new era for ocean data access and regional resilience
articles.author: Fredrick Kusu
articles.summary: The Pacific Community (SPC) announces the launch of its revamped Pacific Ocean Portal. The portal is a digital platform designed to empower Pacific Island nations with user-friendly, open access and actionable ocean data. It was developed in 2012 by the Australian Bureau of Meteorology under COSPPac Phase 1. It supports informed decision-making in marine conservation, maritime safety, tourism, fisheries, and disaster resilience.

articles.title: High praise for a community group's world-setting climate change legal success
articles.summary: DAMSHEG triumphs in NSW Supreme Court, changing coal mine approvals to consider climate impact, as it did in the previous court case.    .   in the current court case, it was changed to consider the impact on the environment.

articles.title: Australia's Tasmania urges stronger action as feral deer numbers surge
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Tasmania's feral deer population has surged by nearly 20,000 in five years, prompting calls from government and industry to strengthen control measures. A third aerial survey is planned for 2027 alongside a new Deer Plan to replace the current strategy. Deer were introduced to Tasmania in the 1800s.

articles.title: Negros Occidental  incurs P6.3 million agricultural  damage from Opong
articles.author: Gilbert Bayoran
articles.summary: Opong has caused P6.3 million in damage to Negros Occidental agriculture industry due to Severe Tropical Storm Opong. Up to 259 hectares of rice fields in 39 barangays were damaged and 351 farmers were displaced by floodwaters. The storm affected 12 households in Valladolid town and in the cities of Bago and La Carlota. 36 heads of livestock were evacuated to a rescue center in Moises Padilla before Opong struck.

articles.title: Badenoch vows to scrap ‘failed' climate change law
articles.author: The Daily Telegraph
articles.summary: "We need to do what we can sensibly do to tackle climate change, but we cannot do it alone. If other countries aren't doing it, then us being the goody two-shoes of the world is not encouraging anyone to improve.

articles.title: Swiss glaciers shrank 3% this year, the fourth-biggest retreat on record
articles.author: Houston Chronicle
articles.summary: Swiss glaciers have seen a 3% drop in total volume this year. This is the fourth-largest annual decline on record. Global warming is to blame for the decline, according to Swiss glaciologists.   Â      .

articles.title: India weakens Australia's met coal outlook: IEEFA
articles.author: Kallanish Commodities
articles.summary: Australia's optimism over India sustaining its metallurgical coal demand faces rising risks, Kallanish notes from a report by Kallishanker.       .   for Australia's optimism about India's metallurgical coal demand.

articles.title: Most of China's coastal solar is in low-risk typhoon areas
articles.author: PV Magazine
articles.summary: A Beijing-based research team has analyzed the risk to typhoons experienced by solar farms in China's coastal regions. It found 84% of photovoltaic expansion has occurred in areas at low risk of typhoons. Around 16% of solar farms are located in areas deemed high risk.

articles.title: Unexpected region of the Amazon is experiencing 'alarming' rapid growth in climate extremes
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: An unexpected region of the Amazon is at the forefront of rapid growth in climate extremes, according to a new report.    The report was published by the Centre for International Policy Studies (Cipressa). It claims that the region is experiencing a rise in extreme weather events.

articles.title: Sun Safety Under Scrutiny As We Navigate Sunscreen Recalls
articles.author: Greek City Times
articles.summary: As we enter the Aussie summertime, the morning sun is waking us up and it sounds like "get out of bed".    .   It sounds like the Aussies are saying "get up and get out of the bed."

articles.title: Another round of heat records broken across Manitoba
articles.author: CTV
articles.summary: The first day of October brought another bout of record-setting heat across Manitoba, with temperatures reaching over 30 degrees C.    in many parts of the province. In Winnipeg, it reached 30 C. in some areas. in others it was less than 20 C.

articles.title: Australia's Tasmania urges stronger action as feral deer numbers surge
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Tasmanian state's feral deer population has surged by nearly 20,000 in five years. Government and industry are working to strengthen control measures. A survey conducted in October 2024 estimated the population at 71,655, up from previous estimate of 50,000.

articles.title: The exodus of oasis dwellers: In Mauritania, climate change is threatening date farmers
articles.author: France24
articles.summary: In the oasis of the Mauritanian Sahara, climate change is tightening its grip on date palms. The date palms depend on shallow groundwater reserves, which are at risk due to climate change in the area. The oasis is the main refuge for date palms in the region.

articles.title: Gaza latest: Protests erupt around world after Israel detains Greta Thunberg on aid flotilla
articles.author: Virtual Jerusalem
articles.summary: Protests have erupted around the world after Israel's interception of Greta Thunberg's aid flotilla. UK government says it is 'very dissatisfied' with Israel's actions and calls it 'very concerning'.    Google Alert – Israel.

articles.title: Mr Pope in Italy says climate change is real, quit lying about. What is his Fark handle?
articles.summary: The Pope, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, Donald Trump, Arnold Schwarzenegger, and Pope Leo XIV are all climate change deniers. They are also Donald Trump and Arnold Schwarzenegger's political opponents on global warming and other issues related to climate change.

articles.title: La Niña forecast to hit Uruguay's agriculture
articles.summary: The La Niña climate phenomenon is predicted to affect Uruguay during the 2025-2026 season. The combination of above-average heat and below-average precipitation is projected to begin in the spring of 2025, intensifying through the summer. This is expected to pose a significant risk to agriculture, exacerbating the drought vulnerability Uruguay has experienced in recent years.

articles.title: Navigating Bhutan's migration challenge
articles.summary: The recent World Bank report 'Migration Dynamics in Bhutan: Recent Trends, Drivers, and Implications', has brought to light a phenomenon many Bhutanese have known for years. The educated youth and professionals are leaving Bhutan for opportunities abroad, particularly Australia.

articles.title: 30 Million Birds flew over the Sunshine State this week – fall migration is on
articles.author: From Orange Audubon
articles.summary: A Rose-breasted Grosbeak migrates through Florida during the fall. Photo by Louis Martin, Audubon Photography Awards, taken on Thursday, October 2, 2025 at 8:30 p.m. EST.    .
